message.raw:
Fixes issue #18, where adding shots to lyse failed with pandas >= 0.18.
concat_with_padding now only tries to concatenate non-empty DataFrames.

Modified pandas requirement accordingly, with no upper limit on version.
Modified labscript_utils requirement to allow above version specification.

concat_with_padding now only tries to concatenate non-empty DataFrames.

Modified pandas requirement accordingly, with no upper limit on version.
Modified labscript_utils requirement to allow above version specification.

message.raw:
Fixes #17 by speeding up dataframe transfers.

Moved call to df.convert_objects to the lyse server, which makes dataframes more
efficiently picklable by replacing columns containing only a single array datatype
with an array of that datatype. Previously df.convert_obects was only called
after the transfer, so the preceding pickling was slow.

For the large, mostly numeric dataframe tested, this speeds
up pickling and unpickling by approx a factor of 5.

Also set convert_numeric=False in the call to df.convert_objects. It was
previously set to True, but I don't think this is what we want. With it False,
all-numeric columns are still converted as desired. With it True, *strings* are
converted to numbers even if only a single string is convertible to a numeric
value, with all non-convertable values in the column becoming NaNs. I don't
think this is what we want. If the user asked for a string, the data should
remain a string. It is presumptuous to assume otherwise and I suspect a
misunderstanding by whoever wrote this line originally.
message.html:

Moved call to df.convert_objects to the lyse server, which makes dataframes more
efficiently picklable by replacing columns containing only a single array datatype

after the transfer, so the preceding pickling was slow.

For the large, mostly numeric dataframe tested, this speeds
up pickling and unpickling by approx a factor of 5.

Also set convert_numeric=False in the call to df.convert_objects. It was
previously set to True, but I don't think this is what we want. With it False,
all-numeric columns are still converted as desired. With it True, strings are
converted to numbers even if only a single string is convertible to a numeric
value, with all non-convertable values in the column becoming NaNs. I don't
think this is what we want. If the user asked for a string, the data should
remain a string. It is presumptuous to assume otherwise and I suspect a
misunderstanding by whoever wrote this line originally.

values.message:
Fixes #17 by speeding up dataframe transfers.

Moved call to df.convert_objects to the lyse server, which makes dataframes more
efficiently picklable by replacing columns containing only a single array datatype
with an array of that datatype. Previously df.convert_obects was only called
after the transfer, so the preceding pickling was slow.

For the large, mostly numeric dataframe tested, this speeds
up pickling and unpickling by approx a factor of 5.

Also set convert_numeric=False in the call to df.convert_objects. It was
previously set to True, but I don't think this is what we want. With it False,
all-numeric columns are still converted as desired. With it True, *strings* are
converted to numbers even if only a single string is convertible to a numeric
value, with all non-convertable values in the column becoming NaNs. I don't
think this is what we want. If the user asked for a string, the data should
remain a string. It is presumptuous to assume otherwise and I suspect a
misunderstanding by whoever wrote this line originally.

message.raw:
Fixes #16, routines not reordering correctly with GUI buttons.

Problem was confusing a passive transformation with an active transformation:

passive transformation: constructing a new list from a list of indices saying
where in the old list each item should come from (what we were doing)

active transformation: constructing a new list out of a list of indices for
where in the new list items in the old list should be moved to (what we should
have been doing)

When a single routine was moved, this simply swapped it with the one above or
below it and so a passive and active transformation of the order are identical.
But for reordering multiple routines at once it gave the wrong result.
message.html:
Fixes #16, routines not reordering correctly with GUI buttons.

Problem was confusing a passive transformation with an active transformation:

passive transformation: constructing a new list from a list of indices saying
where in the old list each item should come from (what we were doing)

active transformation: constructing a new list out of a list of indices for
where in the new list items in the old list should be moved to (what we should
have been doing)

When a single routine was moved, this simply swapped it with the one above or
below it and so a passive and active transformation of the order are identical.
But for reordering multiple routines at once it gave the wrong result.

values.message:
Fixes #16, routines not reordering correctly with GUI buttons.

Problem was confusing a passive transformation with an active transformation:

passive transformation: constructing a new list from a list of indices saying
where in the old list each item should come from (what we were doing)

active transformation: constructing a new list out of a list of indices for
where in the new list items in the old list should be moved to (what we should
have been doing)

When a single routine was moved, this simply swapped it with the one above or
below it and so a passive and active transformation of the order are identical.
But for reordering multiple routines at once it gave the wrong result.

message.raw:
Fixed bug #13 where lyse did not check for duplicate shots when they arrived at
the same time.

Also wrapped incoming files loop in try: except: so it keeps running in case of
similar problems in the future.

message.raw:
Deprecates 'path' global variable inserted into user scripts.
It is still available, but prints a deprecation warning if accessed .
User should use lyse.path instead, which will be set by lyse to the path of
the file being analysed, or to sys.argv[1] if it exists, otherwise to None.

message.raw:
- Fixed bug where large numbers of shots would take extremely long to be be
  removed.

- Sped up adding shots by doing dataframe concatenation ten shots at a time.
  Load time is now dominated by actual time spent reading files.

- Added progress bar for loading shots.

- Removed redundant printlines

• Fixed bug where large numbers of shots would take extremely long to be be

  • Sped up adding shots by doing dataframe concatenation ten shots at a time.
    Load time is now dominated by actual time spent reading files.

- Fixed bug where large numbers of shots would take extremely long to be be
  removed.

- Added progress bar for loading shots.

- Removed redundant printlines

message.raw:
Fixed bug where when there was no analysis routines, but there were shots,
lyse would busily spin in its analysis loop. Now if there are zero routines,
this is considered 100% of analysis routines instead of 0%.

message.raw:
Removed plot options column which never did anything anyway, and now that
plots re-show themselves each run after you close a window, seems less
necessary.

I can't really think of what plot options would do anymore except
show and hide specific plots, but now I'm thinking that's not the right place
for that configuration. Users can for now comment out plot lines in code, and
if we end up with an analysis globals system then users can set globals there
that their code can check before deciding whether to show a plot or whatnot.

for that configuration. Users can for now comment out plot lines in code, and

values.message:
Removed plot options column which never did anything anyway, and now that
plots re-show themselves each run after you close a window, seems less
necessary.

I can't really think of what plot options would do anymore except
show and hide specific plots, but now I'm thinking that's not the right place
for that configuration. Users can for now comment out plot lines in code, and
if we end up with an analysis globals system then users can set globals there
that their code can check before deciding whether to show a plot or whatnot.

message.raw:
Fixed bug where deleting a routine mid-analysis would cause later method
calls on the AnalysisRoutine to raise an exception. Changed it so that
after being deleted, these calls on an AnalysisRoutune do nothing.

message.raw:
DataFrame index rename [('sequence', '', '', ''), ('run time', '', '', '')] to
['sequence', 'run time']. It used to be the latter, before 39aabd2 when the
df.set_index call was changed to spcify the columns with padded tuples.
The concomitant change to df.index.names broke user space analysis code, namely
the df.sequences monkey patch, that calls df.index.get_level_values('sequence').
The monkey patched sequence method could instead use:
df.index.get_level_values(df.index.names[0]), but there's no need for the padded
names anyway.
message.html:
DataFrame index rename [('sequence', '', '', ''), ('run time', '', '', '')] to
['sequence', 'run time']. It used to be the latter, before 39aabd2 when the
df.set_index call was changed to spcify the columns with padded tuples.
The concomitant change to df.index.names broke user space analysis code, namely
the df.sequences monkey patch, that calls df.index.get_level_values('sequence').
The monkey patched sequence method could instead use:
df.index.get_level_values(df.index.names[0]), but there's no need for the padded
names anyway.

summary.raw:
DataFrame index rename [('sequence', '', '', ''), ('run time', '', '', '')] to
['sequence', 'run time']. It used to be the latter, before 39aabd2 when the
df.set_index call was changed to spcify the columns with padded tuples.
The concomitant change to df.index.names broke user space analysis code, namely
the df.sequences monkey patch, that calls df.index.get_level_values('sequence').
The monkey patched sequence method could instead use:
df.index.get_level_values(df.index.names[0]), but there's no need for the padded
names anyway.

DataFrame index rename [('sequence', '', '', ''), ('run time', '', '', '')] to
['sequence', 'run time']. It used to be the latter, before 39aabd2 when the
df.set_index call was changed to spcify the columns with padded tuples.
The concomitant change to df.index.names broke user space analysis code, namely
the df.sequences monkey patch, that calls df.index.get_level_values('sequence').
The monkey patched sequence method could instead use:

values.message:
DataFrame index rename [('sequence', '', '', ''), ('run time', '', '', '')] to
['sequence', 'run time']. It used to be the latter, before 39aabd2 when the
df.set_index call was changed to spcify the columns with padded tuples.
The concomitant change to df.index.names broke user space analysis code, namely
the df.sequences monkey patch, that calls df.index.get_level_values('sequence').
The monkey patched sequence method could instead use:
df.index.get_level_values(df.index.names[0]), but there's no need for the padded
names anyway.

message.raw:
Improvements to edit columns dialog.

Changes are applied instantly and it can respond to the columns changing mid-edit.
It also maintains its state from one opening to the next (sorting, filter string)

This seemed like the best way to fix a bug (things would break if the columns
changed whilst you were editing which were visible. This was because the dialog
exec_() method doesn't actually bloick the main event loop, in a sense it is just
a copy of that event loop. So I couldn't easily stop new shots arriving and
messing with the column structure whilst we were editing it).

Just making the whole thing dynamic seemed like a good fix and is nice
behaviour too.

Added context menu to show and hide selection in the dialog box too.

values.message:
Improvements to edit columns dialog.

Changes are applied instantly and it can respond to the columns changing mid-edit.
It also maintains its state from one opening to the next (sorting, filter string)

This seemed like the best way to fix a bug (things would break if the columns
changed whilst you were editing which were visible. This was because the dialog
exec_() method doesn't actually bloick the main event loop, in a sense it is just
a copy of that event loop. So I couldn't easily stop new shots arriving and
messing with the column structure whilst we were editing it).

Just making the whole thing dynamic seemed like a good fix and is nice
behaviour too.

Added context menu to show and hide selection in the dialog box too.

message.raw:
Got progress bar working in table view.
Fixed issues with keeping track of column labels, we were not storing
the full tuples and this led to duplicate column creation when the number
of levels in the dataframe's column multiindex changed.

Made loading files much much faster. Are now limited by actual speed reading
the files, I think further optimisation here is not useful.

Added checkbox to set all shots active - not functioning yet

message.raw:
Fixed a bug where lyse.data() could not set the index on the dataframe.
It seems maybe something in pandas changed such that the number of dimensions
had to match exactly, and that the code I submitted ages ago that let you
specify only the first string if all others were empty is being bypassed.
Or maybe not. Maybe it's because I'm using a test shot that has not actually run.

Anyway it works now.

specify only the first string if all others were empty is being bypassed.
Or maybe not. Maybe it's because I'm using a test shot that has not actually run.

Anyway it works now.

message.raw:
Can now add a shot! Dataframe and qt model are updated with shot data.
Server works but dataframe appears to be malformed for the conversion that
happens on the other side. This is likely because the shot is one that has not
run yet and so does not have many layers to the multiindex.
This should probably be considered a bug though - it should handle it regardless.

Might move the processing server side if that's possible.

methods are written in a re-usable way such that they can be used by the rest
of the program as it is ported over.

Timezone is now looked up instead of hardcoded (removed google's tz module)
Float values are rendered in scientific notation

Can now add a shot! Dataframe and qt model are updated with shot data.
Server works but dataframe appears to be malformed for the conversion that
happens on the other side. This is likely because the shot is one that has not
run yet and so does not have many layers to the multiindex.
This should probably be considered a bug though - it should handle it regardless.

Might move the processing server side if that's possible.

methods are written in a re-usable way such that they can be used by the rest
of the program as it is ported over.

Float values are rendered in scientific notation

message.raw:
Now uses runmanager's load_shot_globals() function to get shot globals.

That function applies some hacks that we were otherwise applying in several
places. In particular a new hack allows us to use None as a global value.
It is stored as a null h5py.Reference object.

The function is backported to runmanager gtk so one need not upgrade runmanager.
message.html:
Now uses runmanager's load_shot_globals() function to get shot globals.

That function applies some hacks that we were otherwise applying in several
places. In particular a new hack allows us to use None as a global value.
It is stored as a null h5py.Reference object.

The function is backported to runmanager gtk so one need not upgrade runmanager.

summary.raw:
Now uses runmanager's load_shot_globals() function to get shot globals.

That function applies some hacks that we were otherwise applying in several
places. In particular a new hack allows us to use None as a global value.
It is stored as a null h5py.Reference object.

The function is backported to runmanager gtk so one need not upgrade runmanager.
summary.html:
Now uses runmanager's load_shot_globals() function to get shot globals.

That function applies some hacks that we were otherwise applying in several
places. In particular a new hack allows us to use None as a global value.
It is stored as a null h5py.Reference object.

The function is backported to runmanager gtk so one need not upgrade runmanager.

values.message:
Now uses runmanager's load_shot_globals() function to get shot globals.

That function applies some hacks that we were otherwise applying in several
places. In particular a new hack allows us to use None as a global value.
It is stored as a null h5py.Reference object.

The function is backported to runmanager gtk so one need not upgrade runmanager.
